Kate Mandell (Mackenzie Davis) takes on the job of tutoring Flora Fairchild (Brooklynn Prince) at an English estate. She is constantly harassed by Flora's older brother Miles (Finn Wolfhard). Caretaker Mrs. Grose (Barbara Marten) tells her that Flora is haunted by the death of her parents.

This sets up a good moody horror and it has some good actors. After setting everything up, the plot basically stops moving and developing. It feels stuck in place and the story becomes a muddle. Then the movie truly stops in a confused abrupt ending. The style is like an old horror ghost story which is intriguing. If only, the story would flow better than this.

"The Innocents" (1961) is an ambiguous ghost story with the magnificent Deborah Kerr in the lead role. "The Nightcomers" (1971), with Marlon Brandon, explains the behavior of Flora and Miles in "The Innocents". Unfortunately, "The Turning" is a poor remake of "The Innocents" without any explanation of the original story. The conclusion is ridiculous (or inexistent) and never provides the ambiguity of the original film to the viewer. The performances are not bad but the screenplay is terrible and forgettable. If the viewer seeks out an explanation for the story, reads the plot and reviews of the original film to understand the plot. My vote is three.

I like horror movies and thrillers, I like modern takes on period pieces and classics, and I like the cast and am a fan of the director's music videos and earlier film work (i.e. The Runaways). So I expected to enjoy this update on The Turn of the Screw. I did not enjoy it, I'm sad to report. There was too little story or suspense to hold one's attention throughout, and that's a shame.

The cast certainly did their jobs -- Finn Wolfhard is no longer the nerdy little kid, and Mackenzie Davis was convincing in her role as a driven-to-the-edge tutor -- and it was visually beautiful throughout a lot of the film. But early jump scares suck a lot of the suspense out of it all. And a distinct lack of backstory/characterization leaves way too many questions about what, exactly, there is to be afraid of in the giant, creaky house. The little girl's fears are left unexplained, at least in terms of being satisfactory; the huge personality shift in the boy is sort of waved away; and the many unexplained deaths in the history of the estate are just confusing. I kept wondering if cuts had been made to the script or in the editing room, because things didn't flow at all and it really affected the atmosphere.

The ending will drive a lot of viewers to yell at the screen. Our half-full opening night theatre did a lot of groaning and saying, "You've got to be kidding me!" as the credits suddenly began to roll. Maybe that finale would've worked better had everything leading up to it actually added up to more...but unless we get a Director's Cut we'll never know. I wish I could recommend this movie. I can't. Not scary, nonsensical, and not enough to be worth the price of admission. -HV

review_title: Much better than it is getting credit for
review_detailed_main:
It's an odd feeling when you enjoy a film that everyone else seemingly hated. You feel like you missed something (or saw something that wasn't there to see). While I wouldn't go anywhere near as far as to say I loved 'The Turning', or even that is remotely without fault, I would suggest that an IMDb score of 3.7/10 is a crime.

The film is based on the novella 'The Turning of the Screw' which I have never read, nor seen any adaptions of. So this was all new to me. The opening scene in the movie is pretty weak and doesn't get things off to a good start. I say it was weak only because it cuts off so abruptly. It was actually building quite nicely to that point. The opening scene of a horror movie is incredibly important to set the tone for what is to come, so I wish they had extended this a little and made it have more of an impact.

Then early on in the film came a jump-scare that completely caught me off-guard and gave me a genuine jolt. It's very rare that a jump-scare catches me by surprise any more, so I have to give the film props for that. Then in the next 5 minutes of runtime they tried about 3-4 more jump scares (a truly odd little cluster of them) and obviously they had no impact because the audience is ready and waiting for them by that point. A little bit of inexperience perhaps showing through from director Floria Sigismondi.

Something that really surprised me in this film was the quality of the acting. I make no secret of the fact that I find 95% of child actors very annoying to watch. This film had two of them, Finn Wolfhard and Brooklynn Prince, and both were extremely easy to watch. Take into consideration that the characters they were playing were supposed to be unlikeable and annoying and that makes it even more impressive. Also Mackenzie Davis in the lead role thoroughly impressed me. This is one of the stronger acted horror movies I have seen in recent times.

There is a good atmosphere maintained throughout the film, and it all builds towards the ending. I loved the ending. People seem to hate it from what I'm reading, but for me it was the strongest point of the film. It requires some thinking (I had to go back and watch it again to make sure I had it right) but all the clues are there if you're willing to look hard enough. I think people just don't want to think. They want everything handed to them on a silver spoon.

It annoys me when audiences hate horror films that try to mix up the formula and do something different, because that is the reason we keep getting the same old stuff over and over again. You can't complain about every horror movie being the same old thing, but then hate on any movie that tries to do something unique as well. I enjoyed 'The Turning' and would recommend it.

We don't start the Taylor Swift video until NEXT week." Seriously, why was there nobody on set for this asking what in the world was happening?

Also, maybe this is more a personal peeve, but this is another horror movie trying to use mental illness as an easy button and it seriously annoys me. It's 2020 now, let's try a different angle.

review_title: Messy, sloppy- so much potential wasted!
review_detailed_main: Harnessing a large majority of talent, potential, and an interesting setting- The Turning unfortunately has no clear idea on how to handle its own material, and no idea how to manage its own story. I will stop and say, that even though the script of the film is very messy and confusing, I did feel the actors did their best with the material provided. Mackenzie Davis provided a good performance for the lead, even though her character was oddly mysterious and vague for no apparent reason. Finn Wolfhard, Brooklynn Prince, and Barbara Marten also give the best they can to their performances, but unfortunately they fall more victim to the script than they deserved. The film, simply stated, is a mess. It has no clue which direction it wants to take, and instead provides a vague sense of plot, story, and elements, to get by as a film at all. It's often predictable with its scares, full of various cliches, and its writing is often nonsensical and incredibly random, even impulsive. It does have a very interesting premise, and can be interesting to follow at times, but eventually the struggle to watch the film and comprehend it seems far from worth it, and I can definitely see why so many people gave up watching this film, let alone making it into anything worth watching. The editing is horrendous in this film, and possibly why the reason it suffers most. It's ending, as noted by anyone that has seen this film and written a review on it, is quite vague and honestly pretty terrible. It feels lazy, forced, and honestly doesn't make a whole lot of sense. I can see that they struggled with this film, and I almost feel bad for the production team making it, but it is no excuse for the sloppy mess that it ended up turning into (no pun intended). I do adore the look of the film, and some of the atmosphere, but ultimately a compelling setting does not make a compelling film, and it was dissapointing to see the film unfold into such a case. In the end, The Turning is not a total waste of time, but a large waste of talent and opportunity. Here's hoping that Mike Flanagan's series adaptation later this year will do the story justice. Sigismondi's version relies heavily on lazy jump scares, they are somewhat effective but this film could have risen to "rarefied air" if Sigismondi had chosen to communicate the fright visually with a Classically surreal style of psychological horror akin to 1961 The Innocents to deliver fright sequences . I also must be clear the film had such moody, stylish slice of old-fashioned Gothic atmospheric cinematography that ultimately it delivers.

cinematographer David Ungaro creates a terrific atmosphere in and around the stately house. From the chilly but livable grounds, there's a beautiful hedge maze that seems easy to get lost in, a stable of horses, and a koi pond . Inside, there's an indoor arboretum with headless dolls in a bird bath; a creepy sewing room, made creepier with a human-sized mannequin of an old maid; and hidden hallways. The set design is lavish, dripping ambiance and production value.

The acting is first rate .Mackenzie Davis (Tully 2018) sells her performance with warmth and backbone. Davis is quite good, conveying Kate's descent into madness as her restless, nightmare-laden nights worsen and her entire demeanor gradually changes over the course of the film. She might be overwhelmed and seeing things that aren't there, but no matter the real answer, her disorienting confusion is shared by the viewer. Brooklyn Prince (2017's "The Florida Project") and Finn Wolfhard (2017's "It") are both unnerving in their own way, the former playing Flora as a playful innocent and the latter playing Miles as a disturbed adolescent, and Barbara Marten is quietly chilling as the cold Mrs. Grose.

The ending of the film . A little bit of ambiguity that leaves the audience to interpret the rest can be a pitch-perfect way to end a film. In the case of "The Turning," it doesn't end so much as stop with an abrupt shrug. Does a film live or die on an unsatisfying wrap-up, rendering everything that's good about it all for naught? To me absolutely not. "The Turning" proves that there can still be enough to like for most of its run time. The film is about a woman who becomes a governess for a child who lives at an estate. Once there she realizes that the girls disturbed older brother is also back from boarding school. Soon she starts realizing that the children are not what they seem and that there is a ghostly presence in the house related to the wicked former horse riding instructor who stayed at the house. The woman is curious to find out more about all this while protecting the young girl she is tasked to serve.

The best part of the film is definitely the acting of Mackenzie Davis and especially Brooklynn Prince. Prince was tremendous in The Florida Project and she brought a lively energy to this film, and it was needed. Finn Wolfhard is plain annoying in this film and is now in that annoying teenager phase of life. The film opens with the announcement of the death of Kurt Cobain because? The film falls for the usual horror trope pitfalls that plague films today. Jump scares that are so predictable and just not scary. A plot that brings up different issues vaguely but fails to focus on any of it. Above all, the worst offender is the ending.

The ending was heading in a decent direction before doing a fake out that made absolutely no sense. I could hear the theater become perplexed. After that, guess what? Another twist! Not only that but then it fades to black extremely abruptly. I don't know how they came to this conclusion or what the artistic merit to it might have been but it was resoundingly awful. A mediocre horror film at best made infinitely worst by its ridiculously stupid ending.

review_title: Fantasy Island is absurd, but The Turning doesn't even have an ending...
review_detailed_main:
If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)

I... am... in shock. The Turning had tons of development issues, switching directors (Juan Carlos Fresnadillo was the first choice), cast, producers (Steven Spielberg was once responsible for the project), and who knows what else. It's yet another adaptation of the famous ghost story, Turn of the Screw by Henry James, so it was always going to be a challenging task to bring a horror flick with something unique that the others didn't possess. After so many changes, the film finally decided on Mackenzie Davis as the adult protagonist, and Finn Wolfhard and Brooklynn Prince as the young kids.

They replaced everything and everyone, except the people who are behind the main reason why this movie fails so miserably: the screenwriters. With all due respect to the Hayes brothers, but this is the worst kind of a bad film. It doesn't have a single redeemable quality about it. It's a movie about... nothing! It has no message, no purpose, no structure, and last but not least: there's no ending. I'm not joking, The Turning doesn't have an ending. It's like someone abruptly shouts "roll credits" way before any sort of payoff is delivered.

The whole film is a collection of repetitive, dull scenes that only vary in location. Scareless and predictable jump scare sequences spread throughout the entire runtime with no meaning or objective underneath. Close to ninety minutes of build-up to utterly nothing. This isn't one of those cases where the ending is just ambiguous, and people can interpret it in several ways. As baffling as it might sound, this monotonous, cliche, boring horror movie doesn't possess an ending. I have to repeat it, so you actually believe what I'm writing.

Even if I simply ignore that last (nonexistent) act, the rest of the film is still awful. As the viewer, knowing more than the main character about what's happening or what's about to unravel is almost always a lousy aspect concerning the horror genre. Not only there's a lack of a scary or eerie environment, but the narrative raises dozens of logical questions that eventually get no answer. The movie actually starts reasonably okay, it got me slightly invested in Davis' character, but it quickly becomes one of the most yawning-inducing experiences I've had this year.

Usually, I can turn to the acting to help me get through the hardest portions of the film. However, Mackenzie Davis (who I liked a lot in Terminator: Dark Fate) gradually starts to become uninteresting, and Finn Wolfhard delivers the worst performance I've ever seen from him. Brooklynn Prince is good for her age, but she's still a 9-year-old kid, so... you know. Barbara Marten is probably the best as Mrs. Grose, but just like the movie itself, she has no real impact on anything. Technically, the score is weird, and instead of elevating the scary sequences, it turns them into a rock concert. The editing also lacks consistency.

Honestly, I thought that Fantasy Island was a safe bet for the "Worst Movie of 2020" prize, but The Turning just entered the race. As logically absurd as the former might be, at least it has an ending. It's a ridiculous one, but it's, in fact, an ending. The latter not only lacks a payoff to the ninety minutes of build-up, but it has absolutely no redeeming quality. Describing a film in a one-word sentence was never this easy: "nothing". It's a movie about nothing! No meaning, no message, no purpose, no logical sense. An extremely boring journey through a mansion with predictable jump scares, an awkward score, and disappointing acting. It's an emotionless story packed with unanswered questions, and no, it's not one of those "ambiguous narrative" cases. I definitely don't recommend it, unless you desire that frustration of watching an incomplete film.

Rating: F

I think it's very interesting to see people complain about an unanswered question the movie poses, since people have been arguing about that aspect of the book for over a century. I think that to write the film off because it's ambiguous is missing the point.

Mackenzie Davis shines in this film, and the rest of the cast is great, too. The production design is perfect and charming, and the cinematography is striking and at times pretty inventive.

We used to get a lot of gothic ghost stories, but they've been much less popular in the last couple decades, and most of what we've seen has been pretty bad. This movie is a gem in that respect -- a good haunted house movie.

My one complaint is that I think they may have cut some interesting stuff, perhaps to secure a PG-13 rating, which is disappointing. There are things in the trailer that don't make it into the film. Either way, it flies by, and I would have liked to have spent some more time in this world.

Miles is my favorite part of the film, Finn Wolfhard does a great job at a more intimidating and chilling role. I also have a feeling young Brooklynn Prince, who plays Flora, has a bright career as an actress ahead of her. Mrs. Grose is played well by Barbara Marten, but her character is really bland, I didn't know what to think of her during the film or after it.

As far as the film itself, I'm still wondering nearly 24 hours after watching what it was trying to do. I love that the film takes place in the 90's, and the sets look really nice, but what a strange ride this film goes on. When the credits began to role, a number of people (including myself) threw their hands up at the screen, exclaiming "what"? Not only is it difficult to follow, the film isn't very scary. It's more of a Thriller that relies on jump scares to technically make it a "Horror". I guess maybe if you have a fear of spiders, you might get a scare, but otherwise, disturbed is about all you'll be.

I can also give credit for a couple of scenes involving the gate to the house. I wouldn't call them scary, but definitely intense, and I was able to feel for the characters involved.

A few decent things about The Turning, but as a whole, I didn't know where it was going and it ended before I could figure it out. It's like an album with only one or two good songs on it. Kinda disappointing. Perhaps the book has more answers?

review_title: Creepy modern adaptation of 1898 Horror Novella
review_detailed_main: I'm not sure what these low reviewers expect, maybe they are just too used to modern blood and gore horror movies, but I thought this was a worthy adaptation. Creepy and atmospheric the cast does a good job to maintain the suspense. Kate, the central character, is hired to care for a child in a remote stately but spooky house inhabited by only the house keeper and young Flora, or so she thinks. Her elder brother Miles is away at boarding school but soon returns home and trouble ensues. The actors playing Miles and Flora do a great job at 'playing' the two rather spoilt charges - entitled children who have been raised by paid staff after the death of their parents and Barbara Marten as Mrs Grose the the epitome of the tightly wound classic Governess who thinks the children can do no wrong. For a story that was written in the nineteenth century I thought director Floria Sigismondi did a great job at giving it a modern touch without taking it too far from the original's essence. Sure, it's not a movie for everyone but if you like spooky, ghostly tales set in grand surroundings with the gradual suffocating revelation of what the unknown central character has walked into give it a go. It is not the flop others have made it out to be.

review_detailed_main:
I love Turn of the Screw. In its many adaptations, it has been atmospheric, and scary, with overtones of inappropriate activities.

Other adaptations have suggested more sexual elements with suggestions of incestuous intentions to make it more creepy. There have certainly been more elements of the children being possessed by the ghosts of Jessel and Quint so they can be together, physically, which is believable and creepy when Flora is a twelve-year-old. When the girl is only seven (played by a nine-year-old) this is obviously off the table, thus removing a crucial aspect of Quint's depravity.

The saving grace is Brooklyn Prince who, for a nine-year-old, plays a blinder. Totally believable and an absolute delight to watch, in a not-creepy way. We'll see a lot more of her in the future.

Finn Wolfhard was suitably sinister as Miles and also a face we'll see again, I'm sure.

But for the acting from those kids, this would have merited one star only.

You can't just throw together various things that scare people to make a decent horror film, especially when you make the ending as bad as this one is.

There is the really old mansion, a housekeeper who looks like a crone and acts like she hates everyone except the children, who she refers to as privileged but there are many better words for kids like these, spoilt, entitled, deranged and many more.

There's a friend contacted by telephone, who I guess was originally set up as the rescue friend, but she kind of disappears without further mention half way through the film. Couple of ghosts. Or are they?

Do something else with the hour and a half it steals from you (although it felt much longer).

review_title: Leaves the plot with so many holes that ruins the experience
review_detailed_main:
The Turning (2020) is based on the book The Turn of the Screw by Henry James. As of the time of this review, I have not read the novella, but it is on my to-do list. This review focuses solely on the film experience.

In The Turning, the plot involves Kate and the brothers Miles and Flora Fairchild, orphans who live in a secluded mansion far from society. Kate accepted the position of housekeeper as the former housekeeper tragically died. The Fairchild brothers' parents also tragically died. Hum...

The plot is monotonous for a while. The presentation involves a series of expositions that should lead to the main complication, but it doesn't. Kate grew up without her parents, but we soon discover that she has a mother who is admitted to the strangest psychiatric hospital of all, after all, what mental hospital would leave its patients inside an empty swimming pool? Flora also doesn't have parents and that's the connection between Kate and her. However, the connection is weak. The movie wants to make it clear that this connection is natural and obvious, but it doesn't work so well.

Flora has psychological problems because of her personal experiences. Her first interaction with Kate feels fake and forced, which leads us to believe that perhaps Flora is questionable. The film doesn't make that clear.

The film introduces us to the horror element when Flora shows the house to Kate. "I don't walk around that part of the house," Flora says to Kate, referring to the east side of the mansion. The plot does not use this element to develop the story.

Miles quickly steals the show. The plot that seemed to focus so much on Flora and Kate disappears and makes room for Miles and Kate's relationship. Flora, despite being in a poster version of the movie and appearing in several key scenes in the trailers, becomes secondary. This twist causes Kate's interaction with Flora to not gain the strength it should have to justify Kate's subsequent acts.

Miles is the typical troubled son of a tycoon. Spoiled, arrogant, but clearly with internal problems. Kate and Miles' relationship starts off bad and develops into something with little meaning. Miles seems sexually attracted to Kate, but the plot doesn't explore this theme; the plot only focuses on how the children seem to want to disturb Kate with childish but dark games.

As the plot moves towards the maximum event, I felt that the plot was not plausible for themes we see throughout the movie:







The climax is a sequence of unexplained jumpscares. I understand that scares are cinematic techniques, but it got to the point where there were so many that I was anesthetized.

The ending made no sense. I know that the intention is precisely to open up for interpretation, but the questions are so many that the interpretation is that this film got convoluted. The existence of an alternate ending makes it clear that the writers didn't know how to connect all the conflicts they generated. The alternate ending is more straightforward, but doesn't do the plot justice.

When the movie ended, I felt there were too many holes to ignore. Unnecessary scares, scenes that contradict the outcome, open questions. I wouldn't recommend it, either for the horror factor, which is just a collection of jumpscares, or for the story factor, which ends without much sense.
I wish I wish I stared at a wall for 1.5 hours instead of this movie...

review_title: Very poor writing weakens everything else by association
review_detailed_main:
I'm a big fan of Mackenzie Davis, and Finn Wolfhard has demonstrated strong capability. I'm less familiar with Brooklynn Prince, but I know she earned praise fro 'The Florida project.' I liked Floria Sigismondi's work on 'The Runaways,' and while I'm unfamiliar with Chad or Carey W. Hayes, I recognize that they have notable experience as writers. I've also watched other adaptation of 'The turn of the screw' and enjoyed them. All these are fine points in the favor of 'The turning' - set against what I recognize as poor reception, and moreover, I recognize there's a dicey record of trying to update period pieces. I'll watch anything, however, and I was ready to give this an earnest try.

If nothing else is true, this is well made from a technical standpoint. I think Sigismondi's direction is great in terms of building shots and scenes, and the cinematography and editing are quite sharp. The on-site filming location is fantastic, and the work of costume design, and the hair and makeup artists, is rather suitable. The visual effects are also swell, I think, blending seamlessly into the footage. All this is well and good. However, are these the most important aspects of a film? In other regards, I can understand why 'The turning' is regarded so poorly.

Maybe I'm just no longer used to watching horror movies that trifle with cheap jump scares, but there's a massive overabundance here, and they become tiresome quickly. Employed sparingly and fastidiously they can be useful; not like this. The same goes for general "creepy" imagery - there are good ideas here, but too many are just thrown at the wall, and as a result 'The turning' feels regrettably common and unexceptional. I either know that the cast is skilled, or at least trust that they are, but in this it seems like they're forced into small corners as the parts are written rather blandly. Mrs. Grose is hopelessly severe, Miles is merely a monster, Floria is a senselessly happy little girl, and lead character Kate is a very standard horror protagonist. I suppose the acting is fine, such as it is, but the ensemble doesn't have much to work with.

We all know 'The turn of the screw' as a terrific ghost story, and it's been rendered into fine versions in film and TV. At the same time that characters are empty stock material, some of the dialogue and scene writing in this take is plainly contrived. There are robust airs present of supernatural horror, psychological horror, and mystery, but the narrative struggles with all the other elements of the screenplay. And even more to the point, the more that the story ramps up toward major atmosphere, fright, and climactic conflict and character drama, the more it seems terribly overfull, and overly busy - a veritable cacophony of noise both audio and visual, yet without significant substance.

I was prepared to say, up until the last five minutes or so, that I don't think 'The turning' is entirely as bad as popular opinion would hold. Yet those last five or so minutes "turn" another corner, and make one realize how ruefully disordered the writing is. When all is said and done it's almost as though this movie lacks major rhyme or reason; it's sad and incredible how the same novel that produced, for example, 1961's 'The innocents,' and outstanding miniseries 'The haunting of Bly Manor,' also resulted in this. Despite everything 'The turning' had going for it, unfortunately it turned out to be a jumbled mess, and falls short in too many ways to earn favor. There are certainly worse movies out there, but when it comes to adaptations of Henry James' classic, maybe not.

review_title: Decent But Sloppily Executed Plot Twist
review_detailed_main:
I wonder if this movie had any test screenings because if it hadn't, I'm pretty sure it would have benefited from them. The plot twist is where I felt this movie had its biggest flaw. The movie was not perfect prior to it. It used the same tropes a lot of mainstream horror movies have such as setups for jump scares and objects moving even when they don't really contribute to the story. Its 90s references were unnecessary and I barely even noticed them. However, I was actually enjoying the movie. The cast is solid, the little girl was a standout, and the plot became more intriguing as it went along. The movie held my attention and I was never really bored.

And then came the plot twist. Its reveal was oddly abrupt and felt rushed. If the movie had rewrites, the twist probably could have been integrated into the plot much better. However, I think the movie would have been just fine without a plot twist because the climax that preceded the plot twist was actually pretty solid and entertaining. It felt as if there was an ending they filmed but they decided to cut it and insert a plot twist before said ending was shown. The plot twist made a lot of the setup and backstory feel pointless.

I did not hate this movie anywhere near as much as a lot of people did but it would have been better if it weren't for its plot twist. The movie had a lot of interesting ideas but they were all let down by the end.

This movie started quite strong and kept losing coherence at a faster pace to the point of self-destruction. The characters came to be totally unlikeable. Finally, the ending is a true disaster. I can see a universe in which this ending works, unfortunately is executed in the weirdest, most twisted and shock-seeking way possible. Having seen this movie in January 2020, this will be for sure the most disappointing movie experience of the year at least in term of ending... hands down!

The setting, production, acting and casting really does get you hooked into this unsettling story.

The kid from Stranger Things does a good job as the disturbed boy and casting an older boy adds in an element of sexual peril.

A lot of people complain that the ending is bad - they are definitely not wrong - but this lost me half way through.

The story is good as it chugs along, the children slowly becoming more brazen and bizarre with their behaviour but then it escalates too quickly.

When a young man you are looking after breaks into your room at night and tells you he is literally going to kill you or lures you into dark corners where you get stabbed - then it is time to find another job.

This isn't the 1800's - you can just leave.

She phones home complaining that she doesn't like it here (what with the death threats and sexual harassment) but doesn't want to let the little girl down.

I don't know why she feels this way as the odd-ball child hates her too.

review_detailed_main:
The Turning (2020) 2/10🕷👻💩

"The Turning is the kind of horror film that will either piss you off or confuse the hell out of you, all the while being a pile of garbage that will not sit well with anyone."

Horror has not started off strong in 2020, and The Turning poses as the perfect example. The film seems to overstuff itself with irrelevant nostalgia and a soundtrack that's never 90s enough (hint: Nirvana is never played). The characters are cheaply written, to the point where they become more of an eye sore than actually intriguing (Come on Davis and Wolfhard, you're better than this!). The pacing here seems to almost find a wave, however just as it's about to arrive to a proper conclusion, the derailment suddenly hits the viewer, leaving you frustrated; you can never really tell if this is a ghost story or a goddamn psychological horror, but by the film's end, I swear it was a comedy. .

Verdict: The Turning is as bad as they come, and not in the "so bad it's good" way, but in the actual bad way that'll make you beg for your time AND money back.

Discarding it's period setting should've and could've worked if they had just specified a time period. I was so damn confused and it's not like It Follows where not knowing just helps us.

Another part I disliked was the scares. Again, did this movie want to be this atmospheric horror or just a jumpscare pop corn flick? Even the movie couldn't decide it. There's one solid scare and one moment of genuine creepiness but that's about it. Again, the gothic atmosphere is thoroughly underused.

One thing I did like was the performance from Mackenzie Davis, going from annoyed to scared, she really does a good job. All this while we're seeing this story develop as a ghost story and then in the end you make it seem all intellectual or mental or whatever, it just won't work. I just didn't care enough to make my own interpretation.

review_title: Much to unpack ... especially with THAT ending
review_detailed_main:
Somewhere in Floria Sigismondi's film, there is a decent movie. Heck, I'd even say for the first half of this movie, it was a solid B psychological horror film. Definitely something I could play in the background or get lost in this gothic fantasy world of large mansions, horseback riding and maze grounds.

Because I will give credit, that this is a beautifully shot movie with very gorgeous gothic imagery despite the forced jump scares. Floria Sigismondi and her team did create a beautiful "world" with the set production + cinematography.

All the actors were excellent and did their best to elevate the material they were given. Mackenzie Davis, Finn Wolfhard and Brooklynn Prince all played off each other very well. Barbara Marten was also fantastic. They carried this movie and deserved better.

It's a shame the script wasn't written by someone more skilled and nuanced, because there was so much that could have been explored of the ghosts and the children's suggested trauma. Miles' relationship with Quint and Quint's influence/corruption on Miles. Flora's trauma of not wanting to leave the grounds. So much was set up and teased, but never fully explored.

Then there's Kate's trauma of neglect and abandonment issues, possible mental abuse from her mother that's all there in the subtext.

The ending though. THAT ENDING. I definitely see why people hate it. I didn't hate it, but I didn't love it. It makes me think there was an alternate cut and they went with this route, which may have been the "safe" route in the studios' mind, but instead, it effectively threw everything out. The original novella hints at a lot of the dark stuff the kids may or may not have witnessed and this movie seemed like it was going in that direction until the last 10 minutes.

review_title: Henry James is Rolling in His Grave
review_detailed_main: "The Turn of the Screw" was a chilling work of classic gothic literature; a twisting tale of madness and terror. It was model for all future horror stories. "The Turning," on the other hand... one can't say the same for it. Every unsettling, ambiguous plot point of "The Turn of the Screw" was exchanged for some cheap jump-scare or unnecessary display of mediocre CGI. Characters were completely changed simply for the sake of being superfluously creepy and thereby discarding any of their original substance. However, none of the frightening scenes from the book (for example, Quint on the stairs or looking in through the window) were used in the film. The only reference to the novella's ambiguity came from an unclear ending, which only confused the audience instead of encouraging them to discuss Kate's sanity and whether the house was actually haunted. In conclusion, this movie missed the point and Henry James deserved better.

At the very least, the two were engaged in a horrific process of grooming with the children, and the text dances around it a lot but it makes it a really horrifying story.

Filming this would be difficult. The actors for the most part are giving their all to this script, and there are some commendably coherent performances. The cinematography is decent and the Victorian mansion motif is very consistent with the story. I think it's a good looking film.

There are also some huge problems with the mood and pacing, and some awkward and stilted scenes that are actually kind of bad. I would still recommend watching this. Go and expecting to laugh once in a while, and be prepared to hate some of the parts of the film, but I command the actors with some exceptions for their work here.

The ending tried to do too many things, failing to execute any of them well. I can understand why so many people are confused as to the ending.

I am quite surprised the ambiguity that plays such and important role in The Turn of the Screw's reputation as a gothic horror novel was kept in this new iteration, given how allergic Hollywood and american audiences are when it come to ambiguous endings and unanswered questions in films. On the other hand, and not surprisingly, the sexual elements of the story seem to have been completely ignored, which is a great shame as these are what makes everything far more disturbing. This adaptation is fairly entertaining but too hollywood (jumpscares galore), the "modern" setting did not serve any purpose either. I'd recommend watching Jack Clayton's masterful "The Innocents" and the film version of Benjamin Britten's opera from 1982 available on youtube; hell, even the 2009 BBC version is a descent take of this iconic "ghost" tale. Also all of the aforementioned adaptations keep the sexual implications intact, particularly Britten's opera.

review_title: Hammers all the subtlety out of the original, but worth a look if you can step it out of that shadow
review_detailed_main:
As a remake of The Turn Of The Screw/Les Innocents, this was distinctly heavyhanded and overwrought. The power in that original story is how much is left up to interpretation; is it a haunting or a descent into madness? Is it a supernatural horror or a psychological thriller? Just exactly *how* close were the dearly departed to the children in their care? And the harrowing darkness of that original ending lends the film entire much of its impact. The Turn belabours too much to do an adaptation of that story tonal justice, while explaining too little to be a fair introduction of any new viewer to the tale.

HOWEVER, that said; this is a reasonably high-quality distinctly post-2000s -style horror when taken on its own merit. The production values were fantastic throughout, performances nuanced and convincing, and the tension built deftly. The now-ubiquitous jump scare tool was used in good balance with genuinely effecting suspense, and after the initial introductory slow-burn, the pace, once it picks up, escalates frenetically by the minute - to point where the hectic whirl of events has the viewer completely along for the ride with our heroine in no longer knowing what's real or not. It's certainly better-acted and more emotionally compelling than the bulk of its contemporary fare.

So, the TL version is; if you're looking for a delicately-woven and slowly-played gothic horror with an ending of guttingly horrific tragedy, then look elsewhere. If you're in the market for ghosts and gasps with some solid performances and a breakneck pace post-orientation, as well as a close-up portrait of a likeable protagonist rapidly degenerating under trying conditions, then you could do a lot worse. A modern take on Henry James' "The Turn of the Screw," Floria Sigismondi's "The Turning" has a grunge music, a historical backdrop, and female connotations. But the movie isn't quite a masterpiece because it doesn't have a thrilling, nerve-jangling plot or an intriguing conclusion.

Teacher Kate, full of personality, is made governess of Bly Manor, a spooky house with Gothic architecture and twisting vines. The loss of her parents has traumatized 7-year-old Flora. Mrs. Grose is a spectral figure at the mansion. When Miles, Flora's 15-year-old brother, returns home with a demonic presence and threatens Kate's mental stability, her determination is put to the test.

A contemporary perspective on the topics of women's tendency toward lunacy and denial is The Innocents. Kate and Mrs. Grose play opposing female characters in the movie, and their connection serves to highlight the topics. The use of light and shadow in the film's lighting and clothing designs highlights their artistic value. The way the movie depicts Kate's insanity and the different outfits give the story more nuance. Prince, Davis, and Wolfhard's performances enhance the content.

In an attempt to modernize the narrative, the producers crammed it with of superfluous details, such as a vague finale, a #MeToo storyline, and a mid-1990s Gen X dream. Additionally faulty are the unreliable narrator and the foreshadowing, which undermine much of the preceding aspects and fail to add elements for an exciting ending.

This film doesn't make those cliche mistakes of such abundantly tedious flashbacks and such. Instead it only shows the paranoid confusion of what one experiencing this would really feel. Instead, similarly to the book as I've learned, much is left to the imagination and that is what makes it far more unsettling and creepy than exposition and motive vomit being thrown at the viewer in order for them to "get" it. Many ghost films fall to the shallow 'Boo!' moment and not much more. This one was far more sophisticated like I was expecting and satisfying for me not ignoring skepticism, paranoia, suspicion, etc. The premise was simple but executed well. I prefer this kind of realistic ghost stories rather than the "Boo!" Let me exorcise you cause the exposition told me so, drivel that often plagues the more cliche ghost horror like the Conjuring and such. I really think this effort was a step in the right direction to modernize adult horror without the need of excessive gore, peddling religion or entirely over-exposed exposition /flashbacks etc. This film keeps the mystery real, raw, confusing, and creepy without overdoing it. I really hope other viewers can give this a chance for what it is, a well acted mystery thriller from the lineage of great gothic fiction. I was prepared to hate this film but I couldn't as I've found it's a nice companion piece to The Innocents, and is a cut above being far better than the cliche stuff it could have been. Another adaptation of Henry James' The Turn of the Screw. There have been good ones, and not so good; sadly, this is one of the latter. Director Floria Sigismondi gives the impression of having seen James Watkins' The Woman in Black and James Wan's The Conjuring, without actually understanding what makes them work. A director can have all the CGI, all the dimly lit corridors, all the barely glimpsed figures in the world - but if they don't have 'an eye for the creepy' it doesn't work. Chilling ghost stories that get under your skin are hard to do. Every flesh-creep has to be earned; they won't come automatically just because you've turned the lights down and put an out of focus figure in the background. As for the cast, young leads Finn Wolfhard and (especially) Brooklynn Prince are very good, and Barbara Merten (as the house keeper) is excellent. Mackenzie Davis' governess on the other hand is annoying and remarkably ineffectual. Killruddery House in County Wicklow, Ireland, is a suitably spooky location - but it's wasted here. I recommend watching Jack Clayton's classic The Innocents, or Mike Flanagan's The Haunting of Bly Manor mini-series instead. 4/10.

review_title: The end result of a dozen rushed ideas
review_detailed_main: The issue with this film isn't about the acting, the set designs, or the music. All of those things were successfully orchestrated, giving the film a strong sense of atmosphere. It's the plot (or lack thereof) that weakens what had the potential to be an impacting and dark movie. Instead, viewers are given a mishmash of different ideas that weakly revolve around a beautiful setting and compelling characters. The potential and talent are there, but the end result felt unfinished and lazy, which is a shame - with more time spent fleshing out the storyline before rushing it into theaters, 'The Turning' would've been a lot more memorable in a positive way.

review_title: Not Bad, Just a Bit Convoluted
review_detailed_main:
The Turning is not your average horror movie. While it can't exactly be called a masterpiece, it's well-shot, well-acted, and for the most part, well-paced. Though at times it can fall into cliche territory, it mostly remains an ambiguous and bizarre film.

Its strengths lie in the performances of the main actors, especially the performance from McKenzie Davis. She captures very well the sense of paranoia and slow mental decay that the movie tries to portray. Some great cinematography also adds to the film's dark, psychological vibe.

The problems really show themselves in the plot and underlying structure (or lack thereof), specifically towards the last quarter of the movie. While I believe it was the intention of the director and writer to be strange and difficult to follow, I can't help but feel like this film could have been much better with a few changes and resolutions to the ending of the film. Couple this with a few easy-to-predict jump scares, and the movie just doesn't quite reach its potential.

At the end of the day, this film is a unique and intriguing horror movie. It's definitely not for everyone, but those seeking a dark, psychological detour will probably view this one multiple times. It leaves much up to the imagination and leaves the viewer with many questions. If not an instant or cult classic, The Turning is at the very least a fun and intellectually challenging thriller.
